article:
'Topology of a [[membrane protein]]' refers to location of N-terminus of the
protein at the cytosolic or non-cytosolic sides of the biological membrane
occupied by the protein. [http://people.umass.edu/bioch623/623/Second.Secti-
on/11.%20vonheijne.pdf Membrane-protein topology] by Gunnar von Heijne For
example, topology of a protein attached to the cell plasma membrane indicates
location of its N-terminus at the cytoplasmic or extracellular side of the
membrane. Every individual transmembrane segment of a protein also has topology,
depending on location of its N-terminus on the inner or outer side of the
membrane. There are several databases which provide topologies of membrane
proteins including Uniprot,
TOPDB [http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/content/36/suppl_1/D234.full TOPDB:
topology data bank of transmembrane proteins] [http://topdb.enzim.hu/
TOPDB database]  and
ExTopoDB. [http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/26/19/2490.long
ExTopoDB: a database of experimentally derived topological models of
transmembrane proteins] There are several computational methods for
predicting transmembrane domains, both for helices and Î²-
barrels. [http://ca.expasy.org/tools/#topology Links to topology prediction
methods in Expasy]
